{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %}

Why do we need this?

We have identified at least 3 different kinds of loops already:

Learner (training)
Source/Gym (Data Access)
Agent (How an AI takes in data, generates actions)

What is a loop? 

It should be capable of containing inner loops. 
It should be able to handle "phases" that might be similar to each other. 
It should self-describe its structure. 
It should be easy to know which parts of the loop are taking long/short amounts of time.
It should be flexible in state modification.
It should alternatively make it easy show what fields are being changed at what points in time.

A Loop will act as a compiled structure. The actual result will be a compiled list of nodes that reference the original loop.

Loop is a compiled object that organizes the callbacks and loop calls into a possibly repeating sequence.

Literal['order',int] contains a int that should be more than or equal to 0. This determines when a function in the loops should be executed relative to other functions.

class Node[source]

Node(function:Callable, base_loop=None, loop=None, children:List[ForwardRef('Node')]=None, parent:Node=None, order=0, call_on='', call_on2str:bool=False, order2str:bool=False, level2str:bool=False, indent2str:str='')

Nodes are used to generate a static loop. They wrap whatever functions are defined in that loop.

Parameters:

  • function : typing.Callable

    The function to be called on this node.

  • base_loop : <class 'NoneType'>, optional

  • loop : <class 'NoneType'>, optional

    The loop this node immediately reports to

  • children : typing.List[ForwardRef('Node')], optional

  • parent : Node, optional

  • order : <class 'int'>, optional

  • call_on : <class 'str'>, optional

  • call_on2str : <class 'bool'>, optional

    Whether to show the call_on the __repr__ and __str__ functions

  • order2str : <class 'bool'>, optional

    Whether to show the order the __repr__ and __str__ functions

  • level2str : <class 'bool'>, optional

    Whether to show the level the __repr__ and __str__ functions

  • indent2str : <class 'str'>, optional

    Amount and characters to indent the __repr__ and __str__ functions

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %}

Nodes are self organizing parts of the Loop Graph.Their execution order is determined by their relationship in the graph.

{% raw %} 
def on_test()->Literal["order",1]:pass
Node(on_test)
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
anno_dict(on_test)

{'return': typing.Literal['order', 1]}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
def on_test(n:Node=None)->Literal["order",1]:pass
Node(on_test)

on_test
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
anno_dict(on_test)

{'n': __main__.Node, 'return': typing.Literal['order', 1]}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
def on_test()->Literal["order",1]:pass
Node(on_test)

on_test
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
anno_dict(on_test)

{'return': typing.Literal['order', 1]}
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

intersection_idxs[source]

intersection_idxs(a:L, b:L, after_insert=False)

Get the idx where elements in a appear in b. If after_insert=True, the offset the idxs.

Parameters:

  • a : <class 'fastcore.foundation.L'>

  • b : <class 'fastcore.foundation.L'>

  • after_insert : <class 'bool'>, optional

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
original_list=L('a b c d e f g h i j k l'.split())
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
idxs=intersection_idxs(original_list,L('d g l'.split()));idxs

array([ 3,  6, 11])
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
offset_idxs=intersection_idxs(original_list,L('d g l'.split()),after_insert=True);offset_idxs

array([ 4,  8, 14])
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
inserted_list=deepcopy(original_list)
for i in offset_idxs: inserted_list.insert(i,'thing')
list(inserted_list)

['a',
 'b',
 'c',
 'd',
 'thing',
 'e',
 'f',
 'g',
 'thing',
 'h',
 'i',
 'j',
 'k',
 'l',
 'thing']
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
test_eq(offset_idxs,inserted_list.argwhere(lambda o:o=='thing'))
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

class Callback[source]

Callback()

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
class OuterCallback(Callback):
    call_on=L(Outer.on_step)
    
    def before_iteration(self,n:Node=None):
        print(n.loop.tab,n.loop.common_obj,'   OuterCallback called lol')
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

Outer.from_nodes([Inner,FailingInner])

<__main__.Outer at 0x7f10b0936940>
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
Outer.from_nodes([Inner,FailingInner]).run()

--- ENTERING OUTER LOOP ---

	 --- ENTERING INNER LOOP ---
	 before_iteration
	 on_iteration
	 after_iteration
	 failed_iteration
		 --- ENTERING FailingInner LOOP ---
		 on_force_fail
		 --- EXITING FailingInner LOOP ---

	 --- ENTERING INNER LOOP ---
	 before_iteration
	 on_iteration
	 after_iteration

{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
class OuterCallback(Callback):
    call_on=L(Outer.on_step)
    
    def before_iteration(self,n:Node=None):
        print(n.loop.tab,n.loop.common_obj,'   OuterCallback called lol')
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
Outer.from_nodes([Inner,FailingInner],cbs=L(OuterCallback)).run()

--- ENTERING OUTER LOOP ---
before_step
on_step
	 --- ENTERING INNER LOOP ---
	 before_iteration
	 <class '__main__.Learner'>    OuterCallback called lol
	 on_iteration
	 after_iteration
	 failed_iteration
		 --- ENTERING FailingInner LOOP ---
		 on_force_fail
		 --- EXITING FailingInner LOOP ---
	 finally_iteration
	 --- EXITING INNER LOOP ---

	 --- ENTERING INNER LOOP ---

	 on_iteration
	 after_iteration

		 --- ENTERING FailingInner LOOP ---
		 on_force_fail
